'''Leaf by Niggle''' is a short story written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] in 1938-39 and first published in ''[[The Dublin Review (January 1945)|The Dublin Review]]'' in January [[1945]]. It can be found
column3: in Tolkien's book titled ''"[[Tree and Leaf]]"''
column4: and in other places. This is notable because the book
column5: consisting of a seminal essay called "[[On Fairy-Stories]]" and "Leaf by Niggle
column6:
offers the underlying philosophy of much of Tolkien's fantastical writings. 

Leaf by Niggle" is very much an [[#Analysis|allegory]] of Tolkien's own creative process
column9: of his own life. Tolkien wrote in [[Letter 241]]
column10: "It is not really or properly an 'allegory' so much as 'mythical'." On the other hand
column12: "I tried to show allegorically how [subcreation] might come to be taken up into Creation in some plane in my 'purgatorial' story Leaf by Niggle."

column4: lives in a society that does not much value art. Working only to please himself
column5: he paints a canvas of a great Tree
column6: in the middle of a Forest
column7: with many other trees around as well. He invests each and every leaf of his tree with obsessive attention to detail
column8: making every leaf uniquely beautiful (of course
column9: he ''niggles'' over each one!). Niggle ends up discarding all his other artworks
column10: or tacks them onto the main canvas
column11: which becomes a single vast embodiment of his vision.

column2: there are many mundane chores and duties that prevent Niggle from giving his work the attention it deserves
column3: so it remains incomplete and is not fully realized.

column1: At the back of his head
column2: Niggle knows that he has a great trip looming
column3: and he must pack and prepare his bags.

column4: is the sort of neighbor who always drops by whining about the help he needs with this and that. Moreover
column5: Parish is lame of foot and has a sick wife

column1: And Niggle has other pressing work duties that require his attention. Then Niggle himself catches a chill doing errands for Parish in the rain.

column2: Niggle is forced to take his trip
column3: and cannot get out of it. He has not prepared
column4: and as a result ends up in a kind of institution
column5: in which he must perform menial labor each day.

column1: Eventually he is paroled from the institution
column2: and he is sent to a place in the country to work as a gardener in a forest. But he discovers that the forest is in fact the Tree and Forest of his great painting
column3: now long abandoned and all but destroyed (except for the one perfect leaf of the title which is placed in the local museum) in the home to which he cannot return — but the Tree here and now in this place is the true realization of his vision
column4: not the flawed and incomplete form of his painting.

column1: Niggle is reunited with his old neighbor
column3: who now proves his worth as a gardener
column4: and together they make the Tree and Forest even more beautiful. Finally
column5: Niggle journeys farther and deeper into the Forest
column6: and beyond into the great mountains that he only faintly glimpsed in his painting.
